transformed_texts:
The Church. A house of stone and shadow. It has grown dim. Its words, once thunder, now a whisper in the wind.  They speak of dwindling numbers, of souls turning away. Perhaps it's the granite heart, unyielding to the changing tides.  The unyielding stance on the matter of unions between two men. On the taking of a life before its time. On the shaping of a woman's own flesh. These are things that bring men to their knees, things the Church sees as sin. But the world moves on, the sun rises and sets, and the old ways, well, they don't always hold.

There are those who see this, who feel the Church's grip loosening. They speak of a need for change, for a softening of the lines, a willingness to meet the world halfway. The Church clings to its pronouncements, to its ancient pronouncements, but the world whispers back, a chorus of dissent.

And what of the priest? Bound to his vows, to God alone. They say he is a man given over to a higher calling. But is it not a lonely calling? A life of service without the warmth of family, the love of a partner? Can a man truly be whole, devoted to God alone?  The world holds no answers, only questions that echo in the silence.

The matter of marriage, of two souls binding themselves, it ain't a simple thing.  A man and a woman, they're the way it's always been. Or so they say. But what of them drawn to their own kind? Born that way, ain't no choice in it. Like the color of your eyes, the shape of your hand. Can't help but be what you are.  

To say they shouldn't be joined, that's wrong. It's like saying the sun shouldn't rise, or the wind shouldn't blow. They're just livin' their lives. 

The government, they got no business in this. This ain't about laws or borders or the defense of the land. This is about hearts.  Let them love, let them be.  That's all.

The right to wed. A simple thing, a paper. But it seems the world can't grasp its own reflection. They see a shadow, a darkness, a threat to the order they know. They fear the different, the one who walks a path not their own. But love is love. It takes root in the same earth, blooms under the same sun. Two souls bound, two hearts beating as one, what difference does it make if the flesh is the same or different? 

They say it weakens the family.  But the family, what is it? A cage of expectations, a rigid box to hold the heart?  Love knows no bounds, no lines drawn in sand.  It thrives in the spaces between, in the whispers of understanding, in the touch that speaks a thousand words. 

They speak of children, of innocence corrupted. But innocence is not a fragile thing, a thing to be protected from the world. It is a seed, strong and resilient, that grows in the light of acceptance, not fear.  

They cling to dogma, to the pronouncements of men who claim to know the divine. But God, if He exists, does He not see the love in these souls? Does He not hear the beating of their hearts?  Does He not understand the longing for connection, for belonging?

The government, they say, should not interfere. But the government, is it not a reflection of the people? Is it not our responsibility to ensure that the law reflects the truth, the undeniable truth that love is love, that all are created equal?

There is no room for hate in a world that needs more love. Let us tear down the walls, the walls of prejudice and fear. Let us build a world where all can love freely, openly, and without shame.

The pharmacy. That's where I spent the summer. Counting pills. Seeing the names.  Knowing some things are made illegal not for lack of use but for lack of control. A drug ain't no good just 'cause it's wrong. And some things wrong ain't no good just 'cause they're right. 

They got oxycotin in there. Vicodin. Percocet. All controlled. But they're used. They're needed.  It's a line. A thin one. You draw it where you draw it.  Maybe marijuana's different. Maybe it ain't.  It's the same goddamn line. A line drawn in the dust. 

The sickness of it. The fear. These things they call them "drugs". They build up a demon in your head. But the demon ain't the weed. It's the goddamn fear. You gotta face it. You gotta understand.

Alcohol's a friend. A bad one. Marijuana's a shadow. A whisper. You can drown in either one. You just gotta know how to handle it.  We gotta bring it out of the dark. Let the light in.  Let people see it for what it is.  Not the monster they made it. Not the devil they painted it.

The church, it's changed. Not like a storm, more like the slow creep of sand across a stone.  Not as strict as it used to be. When I was a girl, Sunday meant lace and ribbons, matching shoes and purses, like a doll stepping out for prayer. We'd all be there, the school girls, a procession of hushed whispers and starched collars. 

Now, there's a mass for the young ones, a quick thing, thirty minutes sharp.  People come in their beach clothes, sand still clinging to their shoulders, families running in late, a blur of Sunday errands. Even the morning masses, the ones I used to dress for, jeans and khakis now. Khakis, they have their place, but it's not the same. More casual, that's what I see. 

I don't know the church's heart, the politics and whispers that move in the shadows. But this, this I see. The clothes, the faces. 

As for the stories, the ones whispered in hushed tones, about the men of the cloth and the darkness they carried...I don't think we can fix broken things with a different kind of collar. There are men who marry, who still carry the weight of that darkness. It's not the vows, it's the man himself. 

Some say the church should change, allow women to preach, allow men to marry. But what if it's a sickness in the soul, something that can't be cured by rules and rituals?  Maybe the answer isn't in the church at all, maybe it's in the hearts of the men who wear its robes.

The laughter caught in his throat, a dry rasp. At first, the notion hadn't seemed so bad. But the dust of the towers was still settling, the air thick with the scent of ash. And they went in.  Pretexts. The air was thick with them. The Bush men, they spun a yarn about Bin Laden, about Saddam, about weapons that never were.  It chafed, it gnawed. The blood ran cold. The lies, plain as day, whispered from the mouths of men in suits.  

Powell, he went to the world stage, a choirboy with a bomb in his hand. Now he speaks of doubt, of a foundation built on sand. Malfeasance. A stain on the soul of a nation.  

The Constitution, a tattered flag in a hurricane.  They came in with a hunger for war, a thirst for something darker. The treasury man, gone now, whispered of it in his book. A blood debt, an inheritance passed down.  They spoke of energy, of a thirst that could only be quenched in oil fields. 

It went on too long, this war. A serpent's nest, festering. If they pulled back now, the wounds would bleed anew. The UN and their allies,  a patchwork quilt of nations, they talked of order, of peace.  But who holds the hand on the tiller when the ship is adrift? Iraq, a land carved up, its soul bleeding. The parliament, a hollow shell. The Prime Minister, a puppet dancing on strings. Sadr, the firebrand, his shadow stretching across the halls of power. 

The laughter died on his lips. A bitter taste, a truth too raw to speak.

The wind blew through the dust.  The air tasted like metal.  He stared into the machine, the red light a malevolent eye.  "The war," he said, the word a rasp in his throat.  "A pointlessness to it all."  He shifted, a shadow in the sun-bleached room.  "Never a declaration, not in truth.  A reckoning, a score to settle.  A ghost of vengeance."

He paused, the silence heavy as a shroud.  "They say it's for democracy, for oil.  For the good of the people.  But the people, they're caught in the crossfire.  A land torn asunder, a garden trampled.  And what of the boys, sent to fight a war they don't understand, a war that has no end?"

He looked away, his gaze distant.  "Vietnam, a name that whispers on the wind, a ghost of a war that never died.  Will this too be remembered as a mistake, a wound that festers?"

He turned back, his eyes fixed on the red light.  "It's a question without an answer.  A man trapped in a cage of his own making. "

The idea of making it law, of the state laying claim to such a thing, it feels wrong.  A violation. The Constitution, it speaks clear on this. Separation. A wall.  Between the church and the world. Trying to force, to decree, on this matter, that's a defiance, a twisting of what's already been set in stone.  They talk of making it illegal, these men, these politicians. But what right have they? One church's creed over another's?  Look at the Catholics, the Christians. Most turn from it, reject it. Except maybe up north, in those cities with their own kind of darkness. But this, this is not for the government.  

This is a matter for the faithful. Let them decide. 

The Constitution, it was meant to allow for tolerance.  And any amendment, any attempt to bind them, to restrict, it would be a perversion.  A turning against its own purpose.  It would be the only amendment, perhaps, meant to shackle the people, not the state. 

This man, he pushes for this change. Why? Because it goes against his own beliefs, his own God. And in that, he betrays the very principle he claims to uphold. What he wants is for one voice to drown out the others. 

Let the churches decide. Let them be the arbiters.  This is not the government's place.  There is no reason, no justification for this meddling, except for personal conviction.  A conviction that should have no power over the lives of others.

The war. Iraq. A stain. From the start, the words the government spun, they weren't straight. They tied it to the day the towers fell, a thread spun thin. But the day the towers fell, it wasn't the day the road to Baghdad was paved. They played on fear, on the raw grief of a nation. 

I ain't no man for war. Least of all a war fought on a whim, a preemptive strike. This war, it echoed the ghosts of Vietnam, the same mistakes, the same blood on the ground. American boys dying for a land that wasn't theirs, for a cause that wasn't clear. They went in, ripped the government from its roots, and left a hollow space, a void waiting to be filled with chaos. They thought they could plant democracy, like a seed in parched soil, and watch it bloom. They forgot the earth remembers, and the seeds of unrest take root in the darkness.

Like Vietnam, it wasn't a clean fight. You can't fight a nation with flags and uniforms, when the enemy wears the face of the people. You can't bomb away their anger, their desperation. 

They said it would be a swift victory. A cakewalk. But wars ain't cakewalks. They're a slow burn, a festering wound that refuses to heal. They left the people to their own devices, to the ghosts of their past and the bitterness of the present. They left them with a promise of freedom, but freedom comes with a price. A price they weren't willing to pay.

And now, we're still there, years later. The land scarred, the people broken, the dream of a peaceful future a distant echo. The war in Iraq, it's a cautionary tale, a reminder that some wounds can't be healed, some mistakes can't be undone. And the echoes of those mistakes will linger long after the guns fall silent.

The man spoke slow, a rasp in his voice. "Marriage. It's a matter of the soul, ain't it? Some folks, they're born that way. The Lord made 'em so. Seems like science is finally catchin' up. No more of this social rot, this notion that a man can choose his nature. It ain't right, denyin' a soul its right to love." 

He spat a stream of tobacco juice into the dusty street. "Politics, government, they got no business in this. This ain't a law they need to write, a rule to be broken. It's between two hearts, two souls. My neighbor, he's got a man, livin' together like any other couple, walkin' their dog, tendin' their garden. They ain't hurtin' nobody."

He shook his head, a grim frown creasing his weathered face. "This talk of God's will, of man playin' God... it's all a facade. It's fear, plain and simple. Fear of what they don't understand.  Should be a private thing, marriage, a quiet vow between two souls. Not some spectacle, not somethin' for the papers to feast on."

A thing put out there, it stays.  The world's a public square now.  You can't pull it back.  As an RA, I've seen it.  Kids say things, throw things out there, thinking it's just noise.  But it's a stain.  Colors you.  Words about blowin' things up, talk of shootin' ... someone hears. Someone sees. And the school, they gotta act.  They can't just let it hang, let it fester, especially when things get dark.  What if it's not a joke? What if it's a seed planted?  

They say you can't know what's real anymore.  Kids messin' around, tryin' to shock. Or something darker, somethin' that twists and takes root.  There was a kid here, they found somethin' on his page.  Jokes, maybe. Or maybe not.  But in the light of things, it looked different.  Made folks nervous.

The internet, it's a river runnin' wide and deep.  No takin' it back once it's flowed out.  No privacy in the open.  If you don't want it seen, don't put it out there.  Can't tell folks what to think, what to take seriously.  But the school, they can't ignore what's brought to their attention.  Someone tells them, they gotta listen.

It ain't right to be snoopin', not in your own life, not in theirs.  But when it comes to safety, when shadows fall, they gotta tread careful.

The war. It’s been stretched out too long. A good purpose once, maybe. Democracy for the benighted. But the light’s gone out of it. Now it’s just a flexing of muscle. A show of force.  A hunger for dominion. 

And the motives? Questionable from the start. Shadows of old scores. Father’s feud with the tyrant. The stench of it lingers.

If the aim was to bring light to a land shrouded in darkness, that’s a righteous cause. But what of the shadows? What of the whispers of personal vendetta?

The first blow, the shock of it, that spoke volumes. A statement. But the echoes linger too long. Years bleed into years. The purpose wanes. The cost grows.

They say it’s to bring democracy. But the truth seems lost in the smoke and fire. A war for the sake of war.  A victory lap in a race with no finish line.

It's time to let them stand on their own.  Time to turn our eyes inward. To mend our own wounds.  Billions bled dry in a desert far from home.  Billions that could feed the hungry.  Heal the sick.  Build a bridge over the chasm of poverty.

We have our own battles to fight. This war, this endless, pointless war, it's a wound that festers.  It's time to close it.

The question hung in the air, a thin wisp of smoke.  Someone had seen it, that's what he said. Found it online.  A profile, a window into a life.  And stopped it. Prevented something dark.  Was that an invasion, though?  On Myspace, the air was thick with the scent of exposure.  You put it out there, you shared it, like a prayer carried on the wind.  Anyone could see it, anyone could hear.  What you shared, what you kept close, it didn't matter much.  It was out there, a ghost in the machine.

But to have someone watching, someone searching... that felt different.  To sift through the digital dust, looking for signs, for danger.  Was that right?  To single out the troubled, the troubled ones who might slip through the cracks.  The good ones, the ones who wanted to do no harm, they wouldn't need watching, would they?  But you couldn't watch them all, not every profile, not every whispered secret.  It wouldn't be right.  

Still, the world was a strange and shadowed place, even in the bright glow of the screen.  He'd seen it himself, the man who could weave through the digital canyons, finding names, finding faces, finding vulnerabilities.  A girl, a screen name, a chat window, and a meeting arranged in the blink of an eye.  It was a cold, hard truth, that the things you shared, the things you thought were private, could be snatched away like a gust of wind.

And the schools, they tried to control it, to keep the shadows at bay.  But how could they? How could they stop the whispers, the digital rustling of secrets?  The truth was out there, waiting to be found.

The desert wind whispers of folly.  And this war, this endless sandstorm of a war, is a testament to it. To speak of it now, it feels like joining a chorus of the damned, those who saw the folly from the start. But the truth is a bone in the throat, hard to swallow. The sky was full of hawks, they said, and the vultures circled.  The polls told a story, a bleak one, of dissent. The world agreed, even the ghosts of the fallen.  But the high towers in Washington, they clung to their own truths. A stubborn silence amidst the desert’s howl.

They spoke of democracy, a fragile bird attempting to nest in a wasteland. A culture clash, a chasm too wide to bridge.  Saddam, a serpent, yes, but the desert knew better.  It knew the price of such intrusions. They called it liberation, but the desert whispered of another word: quicksand. A slow, sucking pull leading only to ruin.

What is left to say? The desert waits, patient and hungry.  The echoes of their boots still ring in its canyons, a constant reminder of a promise broken.  To stay, to leave, both paths lead to the same dust-filled horizon. A quicksand of their own making, a wasteland of their own design.

The air hung thick with the stink of it. Discrimination.  Like a shroud over the land.  Not just for women, though they wear it heaviest. It clings to the work you do. Women face a glass ceiling, a shimmer in the air that hides the light of advancement.  Even with equality spoken of, men find it hard to bend knee to a woman's command.  Old ways die hard. A woman in the room might have the skills, the knowledge, the hunger, but the boardroom, set in the stone of tradition, might not see her fit for the top.

Men too, though. Fathers staying home, tending children, they are looked upon askance. The world demands the man be out there, the moneymaker. The provider.  But what of the dreams that whisper in his heart? What of the love that binds him to his home?  Society judges, its eyes cold and unforgiving.

Even in the world of fashion, a man's path is shadowed.  If he's straight, they question his worth.  The world sees a man in that world and thinks of a woman's touch. They doubt his knowledge, his vision.

It's a slow burn, this change.  The tide is turning, but it's a slow, stubborn thing. Women rise, men stay home, the world whispers doubts.  But the seeds are sown.   It takes time for roots to take hold, for the soil to shift.

They didn't make it legal, no. Decriminalized it, they did. Dropped it down from a crime, a full-blown offense, to a ticket. Like running a red. You get cited, not booked, not hauled in. But the shadow of it, the stain, lingers. Job interviews, all that. The fear. That's what sticks.  Even decriminalized.  

For the city, it's a different game.  Arrest, booking, court. It eats up money. Appointing lawyers, judges, the whole apparatus. Costs a king's ransom. And for what? For a joint? Plenty of towns, they can't afford the luxury of compassion. They'd rather lock you up. 

But Denver, different breed. A certain… openness. They see the cost, the waste. The money that could be spent elsewhere. Education, the old folks, feeding the hungry. It's a trade-off, ain't it?

But let's be clear. This ain't about making it free for all. Not like cigarettes, hanging from every gas station pump.  That's a different beast altogether. It's still a taboo thing, you see? Smoke it out in the open, it'd be... awkward.  Like a bad dream.

Alcohol, now. That's a different kind of danger.  But weed, it gets under your skin. It changes things. Makes you different. And everyone reacts different. Some can handle it, some can't. 

It's a hard line to draw, ain't it?

The Church. It calls itself the one true way.  Tradition, they say. Time-worn ways. Rooted deep. But the earth shifts. The seasons turn. And the old ways, well, they can become brittle. Like a dried husk.  

They say you must kneel. Every Sunday. Their rules, their rituals. A strict book. A hard line drawn. And who falls outside? They judge. They cast out. The imperfect, the different. The ones who pray to a different God. 

My father, he walked a different path. An Episcopalian. My mother, Catholic.  The Church said no. They wouldn't bless their union. Tolerance? A whispered word.

They preach love. But their love is narrow. A love confined by stone walls and dogma. A love that turns its back on the stray sheep.  

The priests. They hold power. They speak in God's name. Yet some, they walk a dark path. The shadows cling. And the Church, it turns a blind eye.

They say marriage would change them. Make them better. But the darkness, it doesn't need a ring. It finds its own way. A child, vulnerable. A soul craving light. 

The Church clings to its ways. Even when the light fades.

The matter weighs on me.  A question of angles.  Church and state. Two things tangled tight. A knot you can't untie without hurting somebody. Defining marriage.  A sacrament, they say. But is it the government's business? They don't concern themselves with baptism, do they? No tax breaks, no special look. Just a union. Two souls tethered. And if it's a union, why the fuss?  Civil union.  That's what it is.  

Let them come to their own reckonings, let the states find some common ground. Then maybe, just maybe, it could rise to something more. But a ban?  In the constitution?  That's a heavy hammer for a featherweight fight.  The constitution ain't meant for every whim. Some things are bigger. This ain't one of them.

No.

Raised in the fold,  the word was scripture.  But these friends I've got, they walk a different path. A lightness in their steps, a kinship in their eyes. It's not a thing I understand, not wholly.  But the law's a cold blade, should cut both ways.  Let the states decide. They know their soil, their people. Let them bear the weight of their own choices. A president, he's but a shadow, a man in a suit, passing through.  He don't live in every corner of this land, don't breath the same air, don't feel the same sun.  It's their lives, their burdens. Let them choose.

The thing about Myspace. It's public, ain't it? A bulletin board. A place to post for all to see. If you put it out there, you gotta reckon with what happens next. Folks seein' it, school folk included. No matter what they're callin' themselves, they can find it. Even from their own homes.

Now, school officials, they got a duty. Protect the kids. If that means lookin' at a kid's Myspace, well, maybe it's a means to an end. A way to keep the darkness at bay. Like them lockdowns, the drills they run after those reckonings in Colorado. It's about keepin' the bad things out, from slippin' in.

But yeah, there's a line. A school snoopin' just to catch kids drinkin', smokin', doin' things they ain't supposed to, that's a different story. That's a violation, plain and simple.

Still, if it stops a tragedy, if it keeps the blood from spillin', maybe that's a price worth payin'. Hard to say.  But you gotta understand, once somethin's out there, it's out there. Like a whisper in the wind, it follows you.

The war. It came on quick. Nine Eleven. It cut deep. Made you want to see blood. To make them feel the same. A rage. Blind. They'd done the hurting, now it was our turn. Didn't think much past that. What comes after, who knows.  

Went in unprepared. Like a dog at a fight, teeth bared, no plan. It backfired.  Big time.

They're fighting amongst themselves. That's what they do. Us over there, it don't mean a damn thing. They tear each other up, no reason, no rhyme.  

Sometimes, I don't know if they're even human. Just animals.  

Didn't know what we'd find. They fight different over there. Savage. Not for country, not for cause. Just to get us out. They want us gone. Maybe that's the only thing they understand.

We were hyped up. Fueled by anger. Didn't think. Didn't see the future. Just the moment. 

Bush, he gave in to it too. The people wanted it, so he gave it to them. A war. A revenge.

But maybe he was right. Couldn't just let it go. Had to do something.  

But we could have done better. Had a plan. A purpose. Instead, it was just a flood of anger. We made it worse.  

We can't change them. They'll always be what they are.  

We're hurting ourselves staying there. It's a wound that won't heal. We need to leave.

transformed_texts:
The Church. A house of stone and shadow. It has grown dim. Its words, once thunder, now a whisper in the wind.  They speak of dwindling numbers, of souls turning away. Perhaps it's the granite heart, unyielding to the changing tides.  The unyielding stance on the matter of unions between two men. On the taking of a life before its time. On the shaping of a woman's own flesh. These are things that bring men to their knees, things the Church sees as sin. But the world moves on, the sun rises and sets, and the old ways, well, they don't always hold.

There are those who see this, who feel the Church's grip loosening. They speak of a need for change, for a softening of the lines, a willingness to meet the world halfway. The Church clings to its pronouncements, to its ancient pronouncements, but the world whispers back, a chorus of dissent.

And what of the priest? Bound to his vows, to God alone. They say he is a man given over to a higher calling. But is it not a lonely calling? A life of service without the warmth of family, the love of a partner? Can a man truly be whole, devoted to God alone?  The world holds no answers, only questions that echo in the silence.

The matter of marriage, of two souls binding themselves, it ain't a simple thing.  A man and a woman, they're the way it's always been. Or so they say. But what of them drawn to their own kind? Born that way, ain't no choice in it. Like the color of your eyes, the shape of your hand. Can't help but be what you are.  

To say they shouldn't be joined, that's wrong. It's like saying the sun shouldn't rise, or the wind shouldn't blow. They're just livin' their lives. 

The government, they got no business in this. This ain't about laws or borders or the defense of the land. This is about hearts.  Let them love, let them be.  That's all.

The right to wed. A simple thing, a paper. But it seems the world can't grasp its own reflection. They see a shadow, a darkness, a threat to the order they know. They fear the different, the one who walks a path not their own. But love is love. It takes root in the same earth, blooms under the same sun. Two souls bound, two hearts beating as one, what difference does it make if the flesh is the same or different? 

They say it weakens the family.  But the family, what is it? A cage of expectations, a rigid box to hold the heart?  Love knows no bounds, no lines drawn in sand.  It thrives in the spaces between, in the whispers of understanding, in the touch that speaks a thousand words. 

They speak of children, of innocence corrupted. But innocence is not a fragile thing, a thing to be protected from the world. It is a seed, strong and resilient, that grows in the light of acceptance, not fear.  

They cling to dogma, to the pronouncements of men who claim to know the divine. But God, if He exists, does He not see the love in these souls? Does He not hear the beating of their hearts?  Does He not understand the longing for connection, for belonging?

The government, they say, should not interfere. But the government, is it not a reflection of the people? Is it not our responsibility to ensure that the law reflects the truth, the undeniable truth that love is love, that all are created equal?

There is no room for hate in a world that needs more love. Let us tear down the walls, the walls of prejudice and fear. Let us build a world where all can love freely, openly, and without shame.

The pharmacy. That's where I spent the summer. Counting pills. Seeing the names.  Knowing some things are made illegal not for lack of use but for lack of control. A drug ain't no good just 'cause it's wrong. And some things wrong ain't no good just 'cause they're right. 

They got oxycotin in there. Vicodin. Percocet. All controlled. But they're used. They're needed.  It's a line. A thin one. You draw it where you draw it.  Maybe marijuana's different. Maybe it ain't.  It's the same goddamn line. A line drawn in the dust. 

The sickness of it. The fear. These things they call them "drugs". They build up a demon in your head. But the demon ain't the weed. It's the goddamn fear. You gotta face it. You gotta understand.

Alcohol's a friend. A bad one. Marijuana's a shadow. A whisper. You can drown in either one. You just gotta know how to handle it.  We gotta bring it out of the dark. Let the light in.  Let people see it for what it is.  Not the monster they made it. Not the devil they painted it.

The church, it's changed. Not like a storm, more like the slow creep of sand across a stone.  Not as strict as it used to be. When I was a girl, Sunday meant lace and ribbons, matching shoes and purses, like a doll stepping out for prayer. We'd all be there, the school girls, a procession of hushed whispers and starched collars. 

Now, there's a mass for the young ones, a quick thing, thirty minutes sharp.  People come in their beach clothes, sand still clinging to their shoulders, families running in late, a blur of Sunday errands. Even the morning masses, the ones I used to dress for, jeans and khakis now. Khakis, they have their place, but it's not the same. More casual, that's what I see. 

I don't know the church's heart, the politics and whispers that move in the shadows. But this, this I see. The clothes, the faces. 

As for the stories, the ones whispered in hushed tones, about the men of the cloth and the darkness they carried...I don't think we can fix broken things with a different kind of collar. There are men who marry, who still carry the weight of that darkness. It's not the vows, it's the man himself. 

Some say the church should change, allow women to preach, allow men to marry. But what if it's a sickness in the soul, something that can't be cured by rules and rituals?  Maybe the answer isn't in the church at all, maybe it's in the hearts of the men who wear its robes.

The laughter caught in his throat, a dry rasp. At first, the notion hadn't seemed so bad. But the dust of the towers was still settling, the air thick with the scent of ash. And they went in.  Pretexts. The air was thick with them. The Bush men, they spun a yarn about Bin Laden, about Saddam, about weapons that never were.  It chafed, it gnawed. The blood ran cold. The lies, plain as day, whispered from the mouths of men in suits.  

Powell, he went to the world stage, a choirboy with a bomb in his hand. Now he speaks of doubt, of a foundation built on sand. Malfeasance. A stain on the soul of a nation.  

The Constitution, a tattered flag in a hurricane.  They came in with a hunger for war, a thirst for something darker. The treasury man, gone now, whispered of it in his book. A blood debt, an inheritance passed down.  They spoke of energy, of a thirst that could only be quenched in oil fields. 

It went on too long, this war. A serpent's nest, festering. If they pulled back now, the wounds would bleed anew. The UN and their allies,  a patchwork quilt of nations, they talked of order, of peace.  But who holds the hand on the tiller when the ship is adrift? Iraq, a land carved up, its soul bleeding. The parliament, a hollow shell. The Prime Minister, a puppet dancing on strings. Sadr, the firebrand, his shadow stretching across the halls of power. 

The laughter died on his lips. A bitter taste, a truth too raw to speak.

The wind blew through the dust.  The air tasted like metal.  He stared into the machine, the red light a malevolent eye.  "The war," he said, the word a rasp in his throat.  "A pointlessness to it all."  He shifted, a shadow in the sun-bleached room.  "Never a declaration, not in truth.  A reckoning, a score to settle.  A ghost of vengeance."

He paused, the silence heavy as a shroud.  "They say it's for democracy, for oil.  For the good of the people.  But the people, they're caught in the crossfire.  A land torn asunder, a garden trampled.  And what of the boys, sent to fight a war they don't understand, a war that has no end?"

He looked away, his gaze distant.  "Vietnam, a name that whispers on the wind, a ghost of a war that never died.  Will this too be remembered as a mistake, a wound that festers?"

He turned back, his eyes fixed on the red light.  "It's a question without an answer.  A man trapped in a cage of his own making. "

The idea of making it law, of the state laying claim to such a thing, it feels wrong.  A violation. The Constitution, it speaks clear on this. Separation. A wall.  Between the church and the world. Trying to force, to decree, on this matter, that's a defiance, a twisting of what's already been set in stone.  They talk of making it illegal, these men, these politicians. But what right have they? One church's creed over another's?  Look at the Catholics, the Christians. Most turn from it, reject it. Except maybe up north, in those cities with their own kind of darkness. But this, this is not for the government.  

This is a matter for the faithful. Let them decide. 

The Constitution, it was meant to allow for tolerance.  And any amendment, any attempt to bind them, to restrict, it would be a perversion.  A turning against its own purpose.  It would be the only amendment, perhaps, meant to shackle the people, not the state. 

This man, he pushes for this change. Why? Because it goes against his own beliefs, his own God. And in that, he betrays the very principle he claims to uphold. What he wants is for one voice to drown out the others. 

Let the churches decide. Let them be the arbiters.  This is not the government's place.  There is no reason, no justification for this meddling, except for personal conviction.  A conviction that should have no power over the lives of others.

The war. Iraq. A stain. From the start, the words the government spun, they weren't straight. They tied it to the day the towers fell, a thread spun thin. But the day the towers fell, it wasn't the day the road to Baghdad was paved. They played on fear, on the raw grief of a nation. 

I ain't no man for war. Least of all a war fought on a whim, a preemptive strike. This war, it echoed the ghosts of Vietnam, the same mistakes, the same blood on the ground. American boys dying for a land that wasn't theirs, for a cause that wasn't clear. They went in, ripped the government from its roots, and left a hollow space, a void waiting to be filled with chaos. They thought they could plant democracy, like a seed in parched soil, and watch it bloom. They forgot the earth remembers, and the seeds of unrest take root in the darkness.

Like Vietnam, it wasn't a clean fight. You can't fight a nation with flags and uniforms, when the enemy wears the face of the people. You can't bomb away their anger, their desperation. 

They said it would be a swift victory. A cakewalk. But wars ain't cakewalks. They're a slow burn, a festering wound that refuses to heal. They left the people to their own devices, to the ghosts of their past and the bitterness of the present. They left them with a promise of freedom, but freedom comes with a price. A price they weren't willing to pay.

And now, we're still there, years later. The land scarred, the people broken, the dream of a peaceful future a distant echo. The war in Iraq, it's a cautionary tale, a reminder that some wounds can't be healed, some mistakes can't be undone. And the echoes of those mistakes will linger long after the guns fall silent.

The man spoke slow, a rasp in his voice. "Marriage. It's a matter of the soul, ain't it? Some folks, they're born that way. The Lord made 'em so. Seems like science is finally catchin' up. No more of this social rot, this notion that a man can choose his nature. It ain't right, denyin' a soul its right to love." 

He spat a stream of tobacco juice into the dusty street. "Politics, government, they got no business in this. This ain't a law they need to write, a rule to be broken. It's between two hearts, two souls. My neighbor, he's got a man, livin' together like any other couple, walkin' their dog, tendin' their garden. They ain't hurtin' nobody."

He shook his head, a grim frown creasing his weathered face. "This talk of God's will, of man playin' God... it's all a facade. It's fear, plain and simple. Fear of what they don't understand.  Should be a private thing, marriage, a quiet vow between two souls. Not some spectacle, not somethin' for the papers to feast on."

A thing put out there, it stays.  The world's a public square now.  You can't pull it back.  As an RA, I've seen it.  Kids say things, throw things out there, thinking it's just noise.  But it's a stain.  Colors you.  Words about blowin' things up, talk of shootin' ... someone hears. Someone sees. And the school, they gotta act.  They can't just let it hang, let it fester, especially when things get dark.  What if it's not a joke? What if it's a seed planted?  

They say you can't know what's real anymore.  Kids messin' around, tryin' to shock. Or something darker, somethin' that twists and takes root.  There was a kid here, they found somethin' on his page.  Jokes, maybe. Or maybe not.  But in the light of things, it looked different.  Made folks nervous.

The internet, it's a river runnin' wide and deep.  No takin' it back once it's flowed out.  No privacy in the open.  If you don't want it seen, don't put it out there.  Can't tell folks what to think, what to take seriously.  But the school, they can't ignore what's brought to their attention.  Someone tells them, they gotta listen.

It ain't right to be snoopin', not in your own life, not in theirs.  But when it comes to safety, when shadows fall, they gotta tread careful.

The war. It’s been stretched out too long. A good purpose once, maybe. Democracy for the benighted. But the light’s gone out of it. Now it’s just a flexing of muscle. A show of force.  A hunger for dominion. 

And the motives? Questionable from the start. Shadows of old scores. Father’s feud with the tyrant. The stench of it lingers.

If the aim was to bring light to a land shrouded in darkness, that’s a righteous cause. But what of the shadows? What of the whispers of personal vendetta?

The first blow, the shock of it, that spoke volumes. A statement. But the echoes linger too long. Years bleed into years. The purpose wanes. The cost grows.

They say it’s to bring democracy. But the truth seems lost in the smoke and fire. A war for the sake of war.  A victory lap in a race with no finish line.

It's time to let them stand on their own.  Time to turn our eyes inward. To mend our own wounds.  Billions bled dry in a desert far from home.  Billions that could feed the hungry.  Heal the sick.  Build a bridge over the chasm of poverty.

We have our own battles to fight. This war, this endless, pointless war, it's a wound that festers.  It's time to close it.

The question hung in the air, a thin wisp of smoke.  Someone had seen it, that's what he said. Found it online.  A profile, a window into a life.  And stopped it. Prevented something dark.  Was that an invasion, though?  On Myspace, the air was thick with the scent of exposure.  You put it out there, you shared it, like a prayer carried on the wind.  Anyone could see it, anyone could hear.  What you shared, what you kept close, it didn't matter much.  It was out there, a ghost in the machine.

But to have someone watching, someone searching... that felt different.  To sift through the digital dust, looking for signs, for danger.  Was that right?  To single out the troubled, the troubled ones who might slip through the cracks.  The good ones, the ones who wanted to do no harm, they wouldn't need watching, would they?  But you couldn't watch them all, not every profile, not every whispered secret.  It wouldn't be right.  

Still, the world was a strange and shadowed place, even in the bright glow of the screen.  He'd seen it himself, the man who could weave through the digital canyons, finding names, finding faces, finding vulnerabilities.  A girl, a screen name, a chat window, and a meeting arranged in the blink of an eye.  It was a cold, hard truth, that the things you shared, the things you thought were private, could be snatched away like a gust of wind.

And the schools, they tried to control it, to keep the shadows at bay.  But how could they? How could they stop the whispers, the digital rustling of secrets?  The truth was out there, waiting to be found.

The desert wind whispers of folly.  And this war, this endless sandstorm of a war, is a testament to it. To speak of it now, it feels like joining a chorus of the damned, those who saw the folly from the start. But the truth is a bone in the throat, hard to swallow. The sky was full of hawks, they said, and the vultures circled.  The polls told a story, a bleak one, of dissent. The world agreed, even the ghosts of the fallen.  But the high towers in Washington, they clung to their own truths. A stubborn silence amidst the desert’s howl.

They spoke of democracy, a fragile bird attempting to nest in a wasteland. A culture clash, a chasm too wide to bridge.  Saddam, a serpent, yes, but the desert knew better.  It knew the price of such intrusions. They called it liberation, but the desert whispered of another word: quicksand. A slow, sucking pull leading only to ruin.

What is left to say? The desert waits, patient and hungry.  The echoes of their boots still ring in its canyons, a constant reminder of a promise broken.  To stay, to leave, both paths lead to the same dust-filled horizon. A quicksand of their own making, a wasteland of their own design.

The air hung thick with the stink of it. Discrimination.  Like a shroud over the land.  Not just for women, though they wear it heaviest. It clings to the work you do. Women face a glass ceiling, a shimmer in the air that hides the light of advancement.  Even with equality spoken of, men find it hard to bend knee to a woman's command.  Old ways die hard. A woman in the room might have the skills, the knowledge, the hunger, but the boardroom, set in the stone of tradition, might not see her fit for the top.

Men too, though. Fathers staying home, tending children, they are looked upon askance. The world demands the man be out there, the moneymaker. The provider.  But what of the dreams that whisper in his heart? What of the love that binds him to his home?  Society judges, its eyes cold and unforgiving.

Even in the world of fashion, a man's path is shadowed.  If he's straight, they question his worth.  The world sees a man in that world and thinks of a woman's touch. They doubt his knowledge, his vision.

It's a slow burn, this change.  The tide is turning, but it's a slow, stubborn thing. Women rise, men stay home, the world whispers doubts.  But the seeds are sown.   It takes time for roots to take hold, for the soil to shift.

They didn't make it legal, no. Decriminalized it, they did. Dropped it down from a crime, a full-blown offense, to a ticket. Like running a red. You get cited, not booked, not hauled in. But the shadow of it, the stain, lingers. Job interviews, all that. The fear. That's what sticks.  Even decriminalized.  

For the city, it's a different game.  Arrest, booking, court. It eats up money. Appointing lawyers, judges, the whole apparatus. Costs a king's ransom. And for what? For a joint? Plenty of towns, they can't afford the luxury of compassion. They'd rather lock you up. 

But Denver, different breed. A certain… openness. They see the cost, the waste. The money that could be spent elsewhere. Education, the old folks, feeding the hungry. It's a trade-off, ain't it?

But let's be clear. This ain't about making it free for all. Not like cigarettes, hanging from every gas station pump.  That's a different beast altogether. It's still a taboo thing, you see? Smoke it out in the open, it'd be... awkward.  Like a bad dream.

Alcohol, now. That's a different kind of danger.  But weed, it gets under your skin. It changes things. Makes you different. And everyone reacts different. Some can handle it, some can't. 

It's a hard line to draw, ain't it?

The Church. It calls itself the one true way.  Tradition, they say. Time-worn ways. Rooted deep. But the earth shifts. The seasons turn. And the old ways, well, they can become brittle. Like a dried husk.  

They say you must kneel. Every Sunday. Their rules, their rituals. A strict book. A hard line drawn. And who falls outside? They judge. They cast out. The imperfect, the different. The ones who pray to a different God. 

My father, he walked a different path. An Episcopalian. My mother, Catholic.  The Church said no. They wouldn't bless their union. Tolerance? A whispered word.

They preach love. But their love is narrow. A love confined by stone walls and dogma. A love that turns its back on the stray sheep.  

The priests. They hold power. They speak in God's name. Yet some, they walk a dark path. The shadows cling. And the Church, it turns a blind eye.

They say marriage would change them. Make them better. But the darkness, it doesn't need a ring. It finds its own way. A child, vulnerable. A soul craving light. 

The Church clings to its ways. Even when the light fades.

The matter weighs on me.  A question of angles.  Church and state. Two things tangled tight. A knot you can't untie without hurting somebody. Defining marriage.  A sacrament, they say. But is it the government's business? They don't concern themselves with baptism, do they? No tax breaks, no special look. Just a union. Two souls tethered. And if it's a union, why the fuss?  Civil union.  That's what it is.  

Let them come to their own reckonings, let the states find some common ground. Then maybe, just maybe, it could rise to something more. But a ban?  In the constitution?  That's a heavy hammer for a featherweight fight.  The constitution ain't meant for every whim. Some things are bigger. This ain't one of them.

No.

Raised in the fold,  the word was scripture.  But these friends I've got, they walk a different path. A lightness in their steps, a kinship in their eyes. It's not a thing I understand, not wholly.  But the law's a cold blade, should cut both ways.  Let the states decide. They know their soil, their people. Let them bear the weight of their own choices. A president, he's but a shadow, a man in a suit, passing through.  He don't live in every corner of this land, don't breath the same air, don't feel the same sun.  It's their lives, their burdens. Let them choose.

The thing about Myspace. It's public, ain't it? A bulletin board. A place to post for all to see. If you put it out there, you gotta reckon with what happens next. Folks seein' it, school folk included. No matter what they're callin' themselves, they can find it. Even from their own homes.

Now, school officials, they got a duty. Protect the kids. If that means lookin' at a kid's Myspace, well, maybe it's a means to an end. A way to keep the darkness at bay. Like them lockdowns, the drills they run after those reckonings in Colorado. It's about keepin' the bad things out, from slippin' in.

But yeah, there's a line. A school snoopin' just to catch kids drinkin', smokin', doin' things they ain't supposed to, that's a different story. That's a violation, plain and simple.

Still, if it stops a tragedy, if it keeps the blood from spillin', maybe that's a price worth payin'. Hard to say.  But you gotta understand, once somethin's out there, it's out there. Like a whisper in the wind, it follows you.

The war. It came on quick. Nine Eleven. It cut deep. Made you want to see blood. To make them feel the same. A rage. Blind. They'd done the hurting, now it was our turn. Didn't think much past that. What comes after, who knows.  

Went in unprepared. Like a dog at a fight, teeth bared, no plan. It backfired.  Big time.

They're fighting amongst themselves. That's what they do. Us over there, it don't mean a damn thing. They tear each other up, no reason, no rhyme.  

Sometimes, I don't know if they're even human. Just animals.  

Didn't know what we'd find. They fight different over there. Savage. Not for country, not for cause. Just to get us out. They want us gone. Maybe that's the only thing they understand.

We were hyped up. Fueled by anger. Didn't think. Didn't see the future. Just the moment. 

Bush, he gave in to it too. The people wanted it, so he gave it to them. A war. A revenge.

But maybe he was right. Couldn't just let it go. Had to do something.  

But we could have done better. Had a plan. A purpose. Instead, it was just a flood of anger. We made it worse.  

We can't change them. They'll always be what they are.  

We're hurting ourselves staying there. It's a wound that won't heal. We need to leave.

transformed_texts:
The Church. A house of stone and shadow. It has grown dim. Its words, once thunder, now a whisper in the wind.  They speak of dwindling numbers, of souls turning away. Perhaps it's the granite heart, unyielding to the changing tides.  The unyielding stance on the matter of unions between two men. On the taking of a life before its time. On the shaping of a woman's own flesh. These are things that bring men to their knees, things the Church sees as sin. But the world moves on, the sun rises and sets, and the old ways, well, they don't always hold.

There are those who see this, who feel the Church's grip loosening. They speak of a need for change, for a softening of the lines, a willingness to meet the world halfway. The Church clings to its pronouncements, to its ancient pronouncements, but the world whispers back, a chorus of dissent.

And what of the priest? Bound to his vows, to God alone. They say he is a man given over to a higher calling. But is it not a lonely calling? A life of service without the warmth of family, the love of a partner? Can a man truly be whole, devoted to God alone?  The world holds no answers, only questions that echo in the silence.

The matter of marriage, of two souls binding themselves, it ain't a simple thing.  A man and a woman, they're the way it's always been. Or so they say. But what of them drawn to their own kind? Born that way, ain't no choice in it. Like the color of your eyes, the shape of your hand. Can't help but be what you are.  

To say they shouldn't be joined, that's wrong. It's like saying the sun shouldn't rise, or the wind shouldn't blow. They're just livin' their lives. 

The government, they got no business in this. This ain't about laws or borders or the defense of the land. This is about hearts.  Let them love, let them be.  That's all.

The right to wed. A simple thing, a paper. But it seems the world can't grasp its own reflection. They see a shadow, a darkness, a threat to the order they know. They fear the different, the one who walks a path not their own. But love is love. It takes root in the same earth, blooms under the same sun. Two souls bound, two hearts beating as one, what difference does it make if the flesh is the same or different? 

They say it weakens the family.  But the family, what is it? A cage of expectations, a rigid box to hold the heart?  Love knows no bounds, no lines drawn in sand.  It thrives in the spaces between, in the whispers of understanding, in the touch that speaks a thousand words. 

They speak of children, of innocence corrupted. But innocence is not a fragile thing, a thing to be protected from the world. It is a seed, strong and resilient, that grows in the light of acceptance, not fear.  

They cling to dogma, to the pronouncements of men who claim to know the divine. But God, if He exists, does He not see the love in these souls? Does He not hear the beating of their hearts?  Does He not understand the longing for connection, for belonging?

The government, they say, should not interfere. But the government, is it not a reflection of the people? Is it not our responsibility to ensure that the law reflects the truth, the undeniable truth that love is love, that all are created equal?

There is no room for hate in a world that needs more love. Let us tear down the walls, the walls of prejudice and fear. Let us build a world where all can love freely, openly, and without shame.

The pharmacy. That's where I spent the summer. Counting pills. Seeing the names.  Knowing some things are made illegal not for lack of use but for lack of control. A drug ain't no good just 'cause it's wrong. And some things wrong ain't no good just 'cause they're right. 

They got oxycotin in there. Vicodin. Percocet. All controlled. But they're used. They're needed.  It's a line. A thin one. You draw it where you draw it.  Maybe marijuana's different. Maybe it ain't.  It's the same goddamn line. A line drawn in the dust. 

The sickness of it. The fear. These things they call them "drugs". They build up a demon in your head. But the demon ain't the weed. It's the goddamn fear. You gotta face it. You gotta understand.

Alcohol's a friend. A bad one. Marijuana's a shadow. A whisper. You can drown in either one. You just gotta know how to handle it.  We gotta bring it out of the dark. Let the light in.  Let people see it for what it is.  Not the monster they made it. Not the devil they painted it.

The church, it's changed. Not like a storm, more like the slow creep of sand across a stone.  Not as strict as it used to be. When I was a girl, Sunday meant lace and ribbons, matching shoes and purses, like a doll stepping out for prayer. We'd all be there, the school girls, a procession of hushed whispers and starched collars. 

Now, there's a mass for the young ones, a quick thing, thirty minutes sharp.  People come in their beach clothes, sand still clinging to their shoulders, families running in late, a blur of Sunday errands. Even the morning masses, the ones I used to dress for, jeans and khakis now. Khakis, they have their place, but it's not the same. More casual, that's what I see. 

I don't know the church's heart, the politics and whispers that move in the shadows. But this, this I see. The clothes, the faces. 

As for the stories, the ones whispered in hushed tones, about the men of the cloth and the darkness they carried...I don't think we can fix broken things with a different kind of collar. There are men who marry, who still carry the weight of that darkness. It's not the vows, it's the man himself. 

Some say the church should change, allow women to preach, allow men to marry. But what if it's a sickness in the soul, something that can't be cured by rules and rituals?  Maybe the answer isn't in the church at all, maybe it's in the hearts of the men who wear its robes.

The laughter caught in his throat, a dry rasp. At first, the notion hadn't seemed so bad. But the dust of the towers was still settling, the air thick with the scent of ash. And they went in.  Pretexts. The air was thick with them. The Bush men, they spun a yarn about Bin Laden, about Saddam, about weapons that never were.  It chafed, it gnawed. The blood ran cold. The lies, plain as day, whispered from the mouths of men in suits.  

Powell, he went to the world stage, a choirboy with a bomb in his hand. Now he speaks of doubt, of a foundation built on sand. Malfeasance. A stain on the soul of a nation.  

The Constitution, a tattered flag in a hurricane.  They came in with a hunger for war, a thirst for something darker. The treasury man, gone now, whispered of it in his book. A blood debt, an inheritance passed down.  They spoke of energy, of a thirst that could only be quenched in oil fields. 

It went on too long, this war. A serpent's nest, festering. If they pulled back now, the wounds would bleed anew. The UN and their allies,  a patchwork quilt of nations, they talked of order, of peace.  But who holds the hand on the tiller when the ship is adrift? Iraq, a land carved up, its soul bleeding. The parliament, a hollow shell. The Prime Minister, a puppet dancing on strings. Sadr, the firebrand, his shadow stretching across the halls of power. 

The laughter died on his lips. A bitter taste, a truth too raw to speak.

The wind blew through the dust.  The air tasted like metal.  He stared into the machine, the red light a malevolent eye.  "The war," he said, the word a rasp in his throat.  "A pointlessness to it all."  He shifted, a shadow in the sun-bleached room.  "Never a declaration, not in truth.  A reckoning, a score to settle.  A ghost of vengeance."

He paused, the silence heavy as a shroud.  "They say it's for democracy, for oil.  For the good of the people.  But the people, they're caught in the crossfire.  A land torn asunder, a garden trampled.  And what of the boys, sent to fight a war they don't understand, a war that has no end?"

He looked away, his gaze distant.  "Vietnam, a name that whispers on the wind, a ghost of a war that never died.  Will this too be remembered as a mistake, a wound that festers?"

He turned back, his eyes fixed on the red light.  "It's a question without an answer.  A man trapped in a cage of his own making. "

The idea of making it law, of the state laying claim to such a thing, it feels wrong.  A violation. The Constitution, it speaks clear on this. Separation. A wall.  Between the church and the world. Trying to force, to decree, on this matter, that's a defiance, a twisting of what's already been set in stone.  They talk of making it illegal, these men, these politicians. But what right have they? One church's creed over another's?  Look at the Catholics, the Christians. Most turn from it, reject it. Except maybe up north, in those cities with their own kind of darkness. But this, this is not for the government.  

This is a matter for the faithful. Let them decide. 

The Constitution, it was meant to allow for tolerance.  And any amendment, any attempt to bind them, to restrict, it would be a perversion.  A turning against its own purpose.  It would be the only amendment, perhaps, meant to shackle the people, not the state. 

This man, he pushes for this change. Why? Because it goes against his own beliefs, his own God. And in that, he betrays the very principle he claims to uphold. What he wants is for one voice to drown out the others. 

Let the churches decide. Let them be the arbiters.  This is not the government's place.  There is no reason, no justification for this meddling, except for personal conviction.  A conviction that should have no power over the lives of others.

The war. Iraq. A stain. From the start, the words the government spun, they weren't straight. They tied it to the day the towers fell, a thread spun thin. But the day the towers fell, it wasn't the day the road to Baghdad was paved. They played on fear, on the raw grief of a nation. 

I ain't no man for war. Least of all a war fought on a whim, a preemptive strike. This war, it echoed the ghosts of Vietnam, the same mistakes, the same blood on the ground. American boys dying for a land that wasn't theirs, for a cause that wasn't clear. They went in, ripped the government from its roots, and left a hollow space, a void waiting to be filled with chaos. They thought they could plant democracy, like a seed in parched soil, and watch it bloom. They forgot the earth remembers, and the seeds of unrest take root in the darkness.

Like Vietnam, it wasn't a clean fight. You can't fight a nation with flags and uniforms, when the enemy wears the face of the people. You can't bomb away their anger, their desperation. 

They said it would be a swift victory. A cakewalk. But wars ain't cakewalks. They're a slow burn, a festering wound that refuses to heal. They left the people to their own devices, to the ghosts of their past and the bitterness of the present. They left them with a promise of freedom, but freedom comes with a price. A price they weren't willing to pay.

And now, we're still there, years later. The land scarred, the people broken, the dream of a peaceful future a distant echo. The war in Iraq, it's a cautionary tale, a reminder that some wounds can't be healed, some mistakes can't be undone. And the echoes of those mistakes will linger long after the guns fall silent.

The man spoke slow, a rasp in his voice. "Marriage. It's a matter of the soul, ain't it? Some folks, they're born that way. The Lord made 'em so. Seems like science is finally catchin' up. No more of this social rot, this notion that a man can choose his nature. It ain't right, denyin' a soul its right to love." 

He spat a stream of tobacco juice into the dusty street. "Politics, government, they got no business in this. This ain't a law they need to write, a rule to be broken. It's between two hearts, two souls. My neighbor, he's got a man, livin' together like any other couple, walkin' their dog, tendin' their garden. They ain't hurtin' nobody."

He shook his head, a grim frown creasing his weathered face. "This talk of God's will, of man playin' God... it's all a facade. It's fear, plain and simple. Fear of what they don't understand.  Should be a private thing, marriage, a quiet vow between two souls. Not some spectacle, not somethin' for the papers to feast on."

A thing put out there, it stays.  The world's a public square now.  You can't pull it back.  As an RA, I've seen it.  Kids say things, throw things out there, thinking it's just noise.  But it's a stain.  Colors you.  Words about blowin' things up, talk of shootin' ... someone hears. Someone sees. And the school, they gotta act.  They can't just let it hang, let it fester, especially when things get dark.  What if it's not a joke? What if it's a seed planted?  

They say you can't know what's real anymore.  Kids messin' around, tryin' to shock. Or something darker, somethin' that twists and takes root.  There was a kid here, they found somethin' on his page.  Jokes, maybe. Or maybe not.  But in the light of things, it looked different.  Made folks nervous.

The internet, it's a river runnin' wide and deep.  No takin' it back once it's flowed out.  No privacy in the open.  If you don't want it seen, don't put it out there.  Can't tell folks what to think, what to take seriously.  But the school, they can't ignore what's brought to their attention.  Someone tells them, they gotta listen.

It ain't right to be snoopin', not in your own life, not in theirs.  But when it comes to safety, when shadows fall, they gotta tread careful.

The war. It’s been stretched out too long. A good purpose once, maybe. Democracy for the benighted. But the light’s gone out of it. Now it’s just a flexing of muscle. A show of force.  A hunger for dominion. 

And the motives? Questionable from the start. Shadows of old scores. Father’s feud with the tyrant. The stench of it lingers.

If the aim was to bring light to a land shrouded in darkness, that’s a righteous cause. But what of the shadows? What of the whispers of personal vendetta?

The first blow, the shock of it, that spoke volumes. A statement. But the echoes linger too long. Years bleed into years. The purpose wanes. The cost grows.

They say it’s to bring democracy. But the truth seems lost in the smoke and fire. A war for the sake of war.  A victory lap in a race with no finish line.

It's time to let them stand on their own.  Time to turn our eyes inward. To mend our own wounds.  Billions bled dry in a desert far from home.  Billions that could feed the hungry.  Heal the sick.  Build a bridge over the chasm of poverty.

We have our own battles to fight. This war, this endless, pointless war, it's a wound that festers.  It's time to close it.

The question hung in the air, a thin wisp of smoke.  Someone had seen it, that's what he said. Found it online.  A profile, a window into a life.  And stopped it. Prevented something dark.  Was that an invasion, though?  On Myspace, the air was thick with the scent of exposure.  You put it out there, you shared it, like a prayer carried on the wind.  Anyone could see it, anyone could hear.  What you shared, what you kept close, it didn't matter much.  It was out there, a ghost in the machine.

But to have someone watching, someone searching... that felt different.  To sift through the digital dust, looking for signs, for danger.  Was that right?  To single out the troubled, the troubled ones who might slip through the cracks.  The good ones, the ones who wanted to do no harm, they wouldn't need watching, would they?  But you couldn't watch them all, not every profile, not every whispered secret.  It wouldn't be right.  

Still, the world was a strange and shadowed place, even in the bright glow of the screen.  He'd seen it himself, the man who could weave through the digital canyons, finding names, finding faces, finding vulnerabilities.  A girl, a screen name, a chat window, and a meeting arranged in the blink of an eye.  It was a cold, hard truth, that the things you shared, the things you thought were private, could be snatched away like a gust of wind.

And the schools, they tried to control it, to keep the shadows at bay.  But how could they? How could they stop the whispers, the digital rustling of secrets?  The truth was out there, waiting to be found.

The desert wind whispers of folly.  And this war, this endless sandstorm of a war, is a testament to it. To speak of it now, it feels like joining a chorus of the damned, those who saw the folly from the start. But the truth is a bone in the throat, hard to swallow. The sky was full of hawks, they said, and the vultures circled.  The polls told a story, a bleak one, of dissent. The world agreed, even the ghosts of the fallen.  But the high towers in Washington, they clung to their own truths. A stubborn silence amidst the desert’s howl.

They spoke of democracy, a fragile bird attempting to nest in a wasteland. A culture clash, a chasm too wide to bridge.  Saddam, a serpent, yes, but the desert knew better.  It knew the price of such intrusions. They called it liberation, but the desert whispered of another word: quicksand. A slow, sucking pull leading only to ruin.

What is left to say? The desert waits, patient and hungry.  The echoes of their boots still ring in its canyons, a constant reminder of a promise broken.  To stay, to leave, both paths lead to the same dust-filled horizon. A quicksand of their own making, a wasteland of their own design.

The air hung thick with the stink of it. Discrimination.  Like a shroud over the land.  Not just for women, though they wear it heaviest. It clings to the work you do. Women face a glass ceiling, a shimmer in the air that hides the light of advancement.  Even with equality spoken of, men find it hard to bend knee to a woman's command.  Old ways die hard. A woman in the room might have the skills, the knowledge, the hunger, but the boardroom, set in the stone of tradition, might not see her fit for the top.

Men too, though. Fathers staying home, tending children, they are looked upon askance. The world demands the man be out there, the moneymaker. The provider.  But what of the dreams that whisper in his heart? What of the love that binds him to his home?  Society judges, its eyes cold and unforgiving.

Even in the world of fashion, a man's path is shadowed.  If he's straight, they question his worth.  The world sees a man in that world and thinks of a woman's touch. They doubt his knowledge, his vision.

It's a slow burn, this change.  The tide is turning, but it's a slow, stubborn thing. Women rise, men stay home, the world whispers doubts.  But the seeds are sown.   It takes time for roots to take hold, for the soil to shift.

They didn't make it legal, no. Decriminalized it, they did. Dropped it down from a crime, a full-blown offense, to a ticket. Like running a red. You get cited, not booked, not hauled in. But the shadow of it, the stain, lingers. Job interviews, all that. The fear. That's what sticks.  Even decriminalized.  

For the city, it's a different game.  Arrest, booking, court. It eats up money. Appointing lawyers, judges, the whole apparatus. Costs a king's ransom. And for what? For a joint? Plenty of towns, they can't afford the luxury of compassion. They'd rather lock you up. 

But Denver, different breed. A certain… openness. They see the cost, the waste. The money that could be spent elsewhere. Education, the old folks, feeding the hungry. It's a trade-off, ain't it?

But let's be clear. This ain't about making it free for all. Not like cigarettes, hanging from every gas station pump.  That's a different beast altogether. It's still a taboo thing, you see? Smoke it out in the open, it'd be... awkward.  Like a bad dream.

Alcohol, now. That's a different kind of danger.  But weed, it gets under your skin. It changes things. Makes you different. And everyone reacts different. Some can handle it, some can't. 

It's a hard line to draw, ain't it?

The Church. It calls itself the one true way.  Tradition, they say. Time-worn ways. Rooted deep. But the earth shifts. The seasons turn. And the old ways, well, they can become brittle. Like a dried husk.  

They say you must kneel. Every Sunday. Their rules, their rituals. A strict book. A hard line drawn. And who falls outside? They judge. They cast out. The imperfect, the different. The ones who pray to a different God. 

My father, he walked a different path. An Episcopalian. My mother, Catholic.  The Church said no. They wouldn't bless their union. Tolerance? A whispered word.

They preach love. But their love is narrow. A love confined by stone walls and dogma. A love that turns its back on the stray sheep.  

The priests. They hold power. They speak in God's name. Yet some, they walk a dark path. The shadows cling. And the Church, it turns a blind eye.

They say marriage would change them. Make them better. But the darkness, it doesn't need a ring. It finds its own way. A child, vulnerable. A soul craving light. 

The Church clings to its ways. Even when the light fades.

The matter weighs on me.  A question of angles.  Church and state. Two things tangled tight. A knot you can't untie without hurting somebody. Defining marriage.  A sacrament, they say. But is it the government's business? They don't concern themselves with baptism, do they? No tax breaks, no special look. Just a union. Two souls tethered. And if it's a union, why the fuss?  Civil union.  That's what it is.  

Let them come to their own reckonings, let the states find some common ground. Then maybe, just maybe, it could rise to something more. But a ban?  In the constitution?  That's a heavy hammer for a featherweight fight.  The constitution ain't meant for every whim. Some things are bigger. This ain't one of them.

No.

Raised in the fold,  the word was scripture.  But these friends I've got, they walk a different path. A lightness in their steps, a kinship in their eyes. It's not a thing I understand, not wholly.  But the law's a cold blade, should cut both ways.  Let the states decide. They know their soil, their people. Let them bear the weight of their own choices. A president, he's but a shadow, a man in a suit, passing through.  He don't live in every corner of this land, don't breath the same air, don't feel the same sun.  It's their lives, their burdens. Let them choose.

The thing about Myspace. It's public, ain't it? A bulletin board. A place to post for all to see. If you put it out there, you gotta reckon with what happens next. Folks seein' it, school folk included. No matter what they're callin' themselves, they can find it. Even from their own homes.

Now, school officials, they got a duty. Protect the kids. If that means lookin' at a kid's Myspace, well, maybe it's a means to an end. A way to keep the darkness at bay. Like them lockdowns, the drills they run after those reckonings in Colorado. It's about keepin' the bad things out, from slippin' in.

But yeah, there's a line. A school snoopin' just to catch kids drinkin', smokin', doin' things they ain't supposed to, that's a different story. That's a violation, plain and simple.

Still, if it stops a tragedy, if it keeps the blood from spillin', maybe that's a price worth payin'. Hard to say.  But you gotta understand, once somethin's out there, it's out there. Like a whisper in the wind, it follows you.

The war. It came on quick. Nine Eleven. It cut deep. Made you want to see blood. To make them feel the same. A rage. Blind. They'd done the hurting, now it was our turn. Didn't think much past that. What comes after, who knows.  

Went in unprepared. Like a dog at a fight, teeth bared, no plan. It backfired.  Big time.

They're fighting amongst themselves. That's what they do. Us over there, it don't mean a damn thing. They tear each other up, no reason, no rhyme.  

Sometimes, I don't know if they're even human. Just animals.  

Didn't know what we'd find. They fight different over there. Savage. Not for country, not for cause. Just to get us out. They want us gone. Maybe that's the only thing they understand.

We were hyped up. Fueled by anger. Didn't think. Didn't see the future. Just the moment. 

Bush, he gave in to it too. The people wanted it, so he gave it to them. A war. A revenge.

But maybe he was right. Couldn't just let it go. Had to do something.  

But we could have done better. Had a plan. A purpose. Instead, it was just a flood of anger. We made it worse.  

We can't change them. They'll always be what they are.  

We're hurting ourselves staying there. It's a wound that won't heal. We need to leave.
